comments.commentBody: I'm sure American consumers can trust At&T, Time Warner, Comcast, and Trump to look after our best interests and not take advantage for their own profits... sure...

The remaining Democratic seat should not be filled with a Tim Wu or a Susan Crawford or a Larry Lessig.  That would be great if the election went the other way. Impassioned dissents don't help consumers. Compromises are going to need to be cut.  Issues are going to have to be triaged. Roadblocks are going to have to be thrown up. Grounds for appeal are going to need to be created.   Democrats are going to have to find a lawyer experienced in regulatory street fighting, one who has been inside the FCC as, say, General Counsel or a Legal Advisor. Perhaps even a former lobbyist. Not an ideologue or a big thinker.

The mega conglomerates are here to stay, they are more powerful than the United States Government, & will be the deciding factor as to who runs our Government.This is hardly a Government of the people,for the people.Hopefully, they will have some spare time to throw some bread to the masses, just to keep them docile.The populist Trump will be in the forefront of encouraging & supporting the Corporate take over of our Government, whom he hopes to take advantage of ,once he leaves office.

We seem to keep forgetting what happens when republicans take over the government. Good old George Bush, remember him? He's the one whose policies resulted in a nation just short of a full depression. What happened to him in 2007? Why, he disappeared from sight, remember? While Henry Paulson was bailing out the banks who were responsible for it in the first place, George was hiding somewhere in The White House.

Folks, the opinion here says that Trump's could be the worst of them, especially with the picks he's come up with to run the show. And if we don't impeach him within 2 years, we may never emerge from this depression.

Taken to its logical extreme, there would be no problem for the Trumpistas to allow Megerian after merger until one company owns the whole economy.

They tried that in the Middle Ages. The one company was called the King.

They tried that in Russia and China. The one company was the state.

Works like a champ, right? Let's not try that experiment again. Monopoly should only be a board game. Competition, with reasonable regulations, is much better.

NOT MY PRESIDENT. EVER.

Just as Tom Wheeler's FCC was constrained in its ability to advance consumer interests, the next Chairman's FCC is going to be constrained in its ability to damage consumer interests. The Administrative Procedures Act, the Telecom Act and the FCC's own process rules are designed to balance interests and prevent destabilizing changes.

Assuming that the Open Internet ("Network Neutrality") rules survive an appeal to the Supreme Court, it will be very difficult to reverse them in the next two or even four years. All of those pages that Republicans liked to complain about in the Order constitute a reasoned justification for the few paragraphs of actual rules. The FCC can't just issue an Order on a 3-2 vote that says"nah, kidding". They are going to have to find a reason that circumstances have changed, if a new Rule is going to stand up in court. Not going to be easy, especially with millions of public comments in favor of keeping things as they are. Probably not worth the political heavy lift.

Three greater concerns. First, a Republican-controlled Congress and President will, but for the filibuster, re-write the Telecommunications Act to defang the FCC. Second, the new FCC has great discretion in interpreting and enforcing their rules. No reason why they can't undermine by neglect. Finally, there are lots of issues on the table, and more to come. The new FCC can do a lot more damage by issuing new Rules than by trying to overturn existing ones.
A cozy alliance. You mean like Barry had a cozy alliance with the airline industry ? That last merger between US Airways and American should have never been green-lighted by the Feds.

Is anybody really surprised that Trump will allow monopolies?  Rich people like to be the only ones with money.  Let the poor people suffer so the rich can get richer.  We will see this in every move of the Trump regime.  Good luck Trump voters, he really messed with your heads.

Actually, a high level of concentration in an industry does mean the industry lacks competition. That's the definition of an oligopoly: limited competition in a market shared by a small number of producers. I think 3 qualifies as a small number. This level of concentration is only justified when economies of scale and/or public welfare outweigh the deleterious impacts of reduced competition.

Utilities are specifically regulated and/or publicly owned for exactly this reason. Telecom runs into to trouble because they're trying to have it both ways. They want to sell you the service and the content. To use an imperfect analogy, let's say you want to run a gas line to your home. The gas company says "Sure but you'll buy your appliances from us." Imagine AT&T manufacturing proprietary cellphones. That's essentially the telecom industry's ideal.

In such a scenario, there'd be no reason to invent the iphone and streaming video would still be science fiction. Let's not even touch on the Orwellian implications of throttled internet access. What say you First Amendment? Tom Wheeler only reluctantly endorsed net neutrality after public outcry and a nudge from Obama. I say once more unto the breach dear friends. Start writing letters. Let's get Tim Wu into the seat asap. He's the one that coined the term "net neutrality" in the first place.

AT&T and Time Warner are not the most dangerous combination. Content may be king, but filter is first/foremost. Google and Facebook are each far more dangerous to competition and consumers, and they are primarily filters; their content is parasitic. If consumers never leave Google and/or Facebook to get their content, then AT&T, Time Warner and other content kings are irrelevant.
Forget DOJ, FTC and FCC enforcement for the next four years [among others!], and look to the most activist [Democratic] state AGs to pick up the slack -- and they will.

Right now, the "to be fair" thing seems like an intellectual luxury. Factfinder, Mr. Pinocchio, must be apoplectic. It may be time to remove the "fair and balanced" gloves because there appears to be only one side wearing them.

In an environment of a receding middle class, internet television will increasingly be a treasured oasis for many. Unfortunately, Americans who like to unwind with some TV can expect no refuge from President Trump's Tea Party style deregulation. They'll pay through the nose, and the best playback signal will be subject to the whims of a handful of providers, artificially manipulating the ratings.  Make Entertainment Great Again?

Democrats need to fight dirty, like Republicans have been doing since Lee Atwater and Newt.  But as we believe more in human decency than Republicans do, that's a hard job.  It's only when the majority of people get their Joseph Welch "have you no sense of decency, sir" epiphany about all of this will anything change.  Look what's going on in North Carolina.
I currently pay Verizon $150 a month and Time Warner $231  a month.  Does anyone think they will give me a deal and my rates will go down?

I'm not sure when, if ever, all those desperately needy folks looking for some Great White Hope to come save the day, are going to realize they've been bamboozled. He is a semi-literate con man who talks the talk but doesn't walk the walk. He is a superficial pompous buffoon. Who else in his right mind would go out in public looking like he does: A clown in orange face and a coif which not only defies gravity but looks absolutely ridiculous, who thinks he looks good? If anyone else had the gall to go out of the house, filled with so much self-delusion, to think they're a hit with the ladies, he'd be laughed at. When an alleged multi-billionaire (he's not) does it, no one dares laugh at the Naked Emperor.

Rumpists, you think that maybe you are going to get a president who will put President Obama to shame. You are about to get the exact opposite.

DD
Manhattan
This Editorial brought to you by Google, Gigi Sohn, George Soros, Public Knowledge, the Open Society Foundation, and a seething Tom Wheeler.

This is why democracy can't last when you combine it with unfettered capitalism. Before too long you get gov't-approved monopolies reinforced by authoritarianism. Throw in a police state and you've got fascism (an Italian invention that has been embraced around the world as eagerly as pizza).  Which seems to be the goal that the R party has been working towards since about 1981. If not longer.

One only needs to look south of the border at the wealth and power attainable through ownership of the dominant - as in monopolistic - telecom and broadband company. How do monopolies benefit small business that Republicans "claim" to be for?

Welcome to the free for all ("all" = ultra wealthy) capitalism. They finally have complete control of all the rules and regulations that kept monopolistic powers and unfettered business and capital power in check. It appears they will no longer have a need for lobbyists since their takeover of our government is essentially complete.

The problem with the greedy is they refuse to understand that unrestrained capitalism is not sustainable. What are they going to do when the very few at the top hold all the wealth while the rest of us are kept in permanent debt (from birth to death)?

My my, what esp you have.  From a few comments and suppositions  the Board is able to determine that all this merger and consolidation will occur even though  the new administration has not even taken their seats yet.  A little quick to condemn wouldn't you say?  And to say that investors and financial analysts are betting that merger approvals will be more forthcoming without any evidence seems a bit misleading.  But then, the Board got the election wrong too.
One more way Trump's beloved "poorly educated" will be raked over the coals...un-affordable telecom and internet to keep them ill-informed and out of the middle class.

what Mr Trump said during the prelims all too often had / has no relation to what he now says......to believe anything the man says is little more than a coin toss.....wish he would preface all future comments, tweets, whatever with a "this is a joke", "this is serious and i really mean it" or "your guess is as good as mine - i got up on the right side of the bed if that helps"......what is truly frightening about the Donald is his total disrespect for all of us, both his constituency and the opposition......one of these days there will be a wake up call and it may not be pretty......in the meantime let's just realize the circus is in town and the show is just beginning

Trampling of healthy regulations, that protect public interests? Bring them on, unscrupulous as they may be, given Trump's irresponsible behavior...and clearly geared towards enriching the already rich and powerful. A similar fate awaits the E.P.A., HHS, Labor, Energy, you name it, no matter how stupid it sounds, and is. Trump is much more than a demagogue, he takes pride in thrashing democratic values, as it entails a basic knowledge and a minimum of fairness towards his constituents, and in that he fails miserably. As does his plutocratic team living in an alternate universe.

"...Such a merger (between Sprint and T-Mobile would almost certainly lead to higher prices for cellphone service by cutting the number of national wireless companies to three from four." Sprint has lost money for 3 straight years and T-Mobile eked out a 2% profit in 2015.  A more likely scenario is one or both go bankrupt and the big two gobble up their spectrum in bankruptcy court making them even more powerful.  This idea that we can somehow see the future and prevent monopoly is patently false.  Better to let them merge and then control them via FCC (maybe not with Trump but he will only be there for 4 years)

If we're really concerned about costs going up more than the rate of inflation let's look at the cost of higher education. And how about medical care? And I won't even go into our grocery bills where we pay more for less every day. Let AT&T and the big boys stay alive. They employ thousands of us. We can always decide for ourselves if we want to pay for their services. We can live without it. Really. College and medical care and food - may be different stories for some.
And so it begins: the dismantling of the FCC and its regulations, and privileging the message of the ruling party. Emperor Trump, here we come.
